message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A mid-diastolic murmur at the apex is indicative of mitral stenosis. Among the options, only hoarseness is a symptom associated with mitral stenosis, as it is caused by pressure on the recurrent laryngeal nerve due to enlargement of the left atrium. Pulsus paradoxus is associated with cardiac tamponade, increased intracranial pressure is associated with brain tumors or hydrocephalus, and hirsutism is associated with polycystic ovary syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of exertional dyspnea and lower extremity edema suggest heart failure, and a mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the apex suggests mitral stenosis, which is common in India. Hoarseness is a symptom of vocal cord paralysis, which can occur as a complication of surgery to correct mitral stenosis. Pulsus paradoxus is associated with pericarditis, not mitral stenosis. Increased intracranial pressure and hirsutism are not related to the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mid-diastolic murmur heard at the apex suggests mitral stenosis. Among the options, hoarseness can occur due to left recurrent laryngeal nerve damage from the enlarged left atrium seen in mitral stenosis. Pulsus paradoxus is associated with pericarditis and cardiac tamponade, which are not mentioned in the patient’s presentation. Increased intracranial pressure and hirsutism are not typically associated with mitral stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mid-diastolic murmur at the apex suggests mitral stenosis, which can cause symptoms such as exertional dyspnea and lower extremity edema. Hoarseness can occur due to left recurrent laryngeal nerve compression, which is associated with mitral stenosis. Pulsus paradoxus is a finding in cardiac tamponade, not mitral stenosis. Increased intracranial pressure and hirsutism are not typically associated with mitral stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mid-diastolic murmur heard at the apex suggests mitral stenosis, which can lead to exertional dyspnea and lower extremity edema. Hoarseness is a symptom of compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve, which can be caused by an enlarged left atrium in patients with mitral stenosis. Pulsus paradoxus is a sign of cardiac tamponade and increased intracranial pressure is not related to the patient’s presentation. Hirsutism is a symptom of hormonal imbalances, which are not related to the patient’s cardiovascular condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mid-diastolic murmur suggests mitral stenosis, which can cause pulmonary hypertension and subsequently exertional dyspnea and lower extremity edema. Hoarseness is a symptom of recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, which can occur due to enlarged left atrium in mitral stenosis. Pulsus parodoxus is a pulsus alternans and is not associated with mitral stenosis. Increased intracranial pressure and hirsutism are not commonly associated with mitral stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the apex suggests mitral stenosis, which is commonly caused by rheumatic fever. The most consistent symptom with this presentation is hoarseness, which can occur due to compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve by an enlarged left atrium. Pulsus paradoxus is a sign of cardiac tamponade and increased intracranial pressure is not related to this presentation. Hirsutism is associated with hormonal imbalance and would not be related to the patient's cardiac condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A mid-diastolic murmur heard at the apex suggests mitral stenosis, and exertional dyspnea and lower extremity edema are common symptoms. Among the options, only hoarseness is associated with mitral stenosis as the enlarged left atrium can compress the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Pulsus paradoxus is associated with cardiac tamponade or severe asthma. Increased intracranial pressure is often associated with headaches, vomiting and altered consciousness. Hirsutism is not associated with mitral stenosis.

Among the options, hoarseness is the only symptom that can be associated with mitral stenosis, which can cause exertional dyspnea and lower extremity edema. The mid-diastolic murmur is characteristic of mitral stenosis. Pulsus paradoxus and increased intracranial pressure are not typically associated with mitral stenosis. Hirsutism is not relevant to this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mid-diastolic murmur heard at the apex suggests mitral stenosis, which can cause exertional dyspnea and lower extremity edema. Hoarseness can also occur because the left recurrent laryngeal nerve runs near the mitral valve and can be compressed in some cases of mitral stenosis. Pulsus parodoxus is associated with cardiac tamponade, increased intracranial pressure is associated with neurological conditions, and hirsutism is associated with hormonal imbalances.
